title: Lecture: Naeem Mohaiemen
hero_caption: Shooting Tripoli Cancelled, Ellinikon airport, Athens, 2016.
description:
A missing can of film

In December of that war year, a communist filmmaker disappeared. A rumor circulated: he had made a covert film, embarrassing to our own side. He had left behind a 16 mm film, hidden inside a can of cooking flour. It may not have been the enemy army that killed him.

Most of Mohaiemen’s work over the last two decades has been a search for mirages such as a missing film canister. The revealed futility of these quests, and the stories to take away the bitter, are the subjects of this lecture.

About the artist
Naeem Mohaiemen combines films, installations, and essays to research vanquished left utopias and incomplete decolonizations—framed by Third World Internationalism and World Socialism. In spite of underscoring a left tendency toward misrecognition of allies, a hope for an as-yet unborn international left, as the only future alternative to current polarities of race and religion, is a basis for the work. Family history as a canvas for thinking through how borders (arbitrary, sinister) and passports (precious, missing) commingle with, and against, class privilege, is a throughline in the work. The film archive within his projects—fabricated, and reanimated—is the site of promise and disappointment. Projects were shown at documenta 14, Athens/Kassel; Ashkal Alwan, Beirut; Kiran Nadar, Delhi; Museo Universitario Arte Contemporáneo, Mexico City; Museum of Modern Art, New York; and the Sharjah, Venice, and Lahore Biennials. Mohaiemen co-edited System Error: War is a Force That Gives Us Meaning (Silvana Editoriale, 2007).

This event will be streamed live.

This lecture is the keynote address for the symposium UNFIXED: Material Challenges in Contemporary Art.
